A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.
A subset is a set where all of its elements are also contained within another set.
Does the concept of a/an Group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Subset to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a subset is defined as a set where all of its elements are also contained within another set. This definition requires the understanding of what a set is, but it does not require any understanding of the operations or additional structure (like a group operation) that might be defined on that set. A subset is purely a set-theoretic concept based on membership and inclusion.

On the other hand, the concept of a group involves a set equipped with a binary operation that satisfies certain properties (associativity, identity element, and inverses). The definition of a group is more complex and includes additional structure beyond the mere concept of a set.

Therefore, understanding or defining a subset does not depend on the concept of a group. The definition of a subset is complete with the understanding of sets alone, without any need to reference the additional structure required for a group. Thus, the concept of a group is not necessary for the definition of a subset to make sense.
